ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: The classroom part of this course (as opposed to the UN internship) is a disaster. Prof. Lee is terribly disorganized -- can't even provide a proper syllabus for the class. The class is largely thought by students who are asked to give presentations. The professor and TA are unable to provide clear guidance on anything. For example, Prof Lee had asked that we work on a group paper for the entire class to submit to several of the UN missions. Weeks went by without any guidance, and the week before Thanksgiving break it blew up with students complaining in class that we were not about to start working on a group paper due next week. He cancelled the paper idea. Here is another example: we had been told we had to submit a 2 page reflection paper after we returned from COP17. A few days after our return from COP17 and after several students had already written their reflection paper, we get an email that says this:"I sincerely apologize for having to do this to you, but it seems the reflection paper is actually five pages. I had thought Prof Lee had given me confirmation of the two page requirement before I sent the email to you all, but there seems to have been a misunderstanding." This is highly inappropriate during finals week. Typical of the class: wait until the last minute to provide guidance on something and then expect students to turn things around immediately.Another big ordeal was planning for the COP17 trip. The professor waited until well into the semester to announce that not everyone would be able to go to the COP, and this created an unpleasant process of selection. A large part of this drama could have been prevented by setting proper expectation, had the professor announced from week 1 that not everyone would get to go to the COP. The budget for the class was known from early on. In the end we worked it out so that everyone that wanted to go could go (by flying cheaper routes and cramming 3 people per hotel room).Prof Lee lacks some social skills, often calling students by their wrong names, or at one point asking students to raise their hands if they were willing to contribute money for everyone to be able to go to COP (this is awkward and inappropriate to ask and should be done privately via email).
Regarding Question 8: "I would give this course an overall rating of"The response is purely on the basis of the class, not the internship component nor the field trip to COP 17.

Question 9: Interning at the UN and traveling to COP17 were invaluable experiences. However, I felt like we were getting a lot more than we were giving. If there was a way for our contribution to be more important/significant, that would make it a more rewarding experience.

The instructor gave the impression of preparing very little or not at all for the class. Nearly all presentations given in class were given by TAs or students, and subsequent comments by the instructor were based on these presentations. The instructor clearly knows quite a bit about the subject material, but makes little effort to share this with the class other than by showing up.Organization for the class in nearly all respects (clarity of assignments, planning for the internship, planning for the trip to Durban) was ad hoc and somewhat improvised, and often carried out at a much later date than would have been convenient for those taking the class. Class time and location were rescheduled in a very cavalier manner that was disrespectful of students' time.

This course would be best considered as a clinic course with two clinical components: 1) weekly internship at the UN with a time commitment of 10-14 hrs per week 2)2 week intensive participation at the annual COP conference with not less than 10 hour/day for 12 days.Both parts of the clinic are integral to understanding, achieving goals and for effective integration of the coursework. Coursework geared toward understanding the COP process, text, and current issues is irrelevant if students are not offered the opportunity to attend as delegates, but extremely valuable for preparing them for the COP if they do have this opportunity.As a practicum students gain both an intimate understanding and experience of the international environmental negotiation process and program work of the United Nations and the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change.

In terms of the Durban trip: couldn't the school / instructor have figure out before the semester began how much money there would be for the COP trip? Having to figure it out mid-semester led to a lot of drama. And, students were left with the responsibility of deciding who would attend -- that led to more drama and required a lot of tie.As for the weekly class:is there no better way to teach about this topic than to have students with very-limited expertise present powerpoints based on the readings? I can learn the same info by simply doing the readings.As for the internship:very interesting but started very late in the semester and required a lot of time.
this class should have more credits, as it takes up a lot of time to travel every week to NYC.
Working at the UN.
The internship at the UN and the end of semester field trip to Durban
The internship with the UN Headquarters in New York City and the experience of attending COP 17 were the best parts of the course.
my mission at the United Nations. It was extremely beneficial to experience how the UN operates and what meetings are like.
Getting to travel to the UN and Durban and being able to learn first-hand from these experiences.
The United Nations internship and the trip to COP 17 in Durban South Africa.
Professor's knowledge of UN systems and practical learning with hands-on experience.
The opportunity to attend the climate change COP as part of a national delegation.

Both clinical components were highly exciting and interesting. Both were amazing opportunities to participate in international environmental work and having the support of our classmates enriched the analysis and depth of what we could achieve.
Durban trip
Durban COP17 participation

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Everything. See question 11.

Course needs a more complete syllabus (presentation requirements, writing assignments, etc, with specifics) - if students are making presentations every week - create this schedule at the beginning of the semester not on the flyLectures need structureInternships should be established within first 2 weeks of class (not 1/2 months later)!professor lee doesn't seem invested at all in the students - like he just shows up for class and isn't engaged or interested in what the students needs/desires areinternship should be much more organized with specific assignments and tasks - internships take up a lot of time so they should be worthwhile and meaningful
The actual class meetings were based on student presentations and I felt like students did not actually benefit from the knowledge of the Professor who has spent years in the UN.
organization of class materials and internship information. It was confusing what readings were assigned each week.

A more structured syllabus (and classes that stick to a plan) would help me gauge my learning and progress better. I would feel more confident and well-prepared going into the conferences if I could reflect upon what I'd learned in a more organized manner.

This course was a hard one to rate/describe because from a practical point of view it was a very useful course that taught me a lot about how intentional diplomacy is done and the internship and trip to COP 17 were awesome and made taking the class totally worth it. BUT the classroom time was horrible. The prof was non responsive to email and the TA did not have the authority or ability to make decisions on her own. The rules of the game keep changing, what I mean is that the prof would come in to class and say "i think we should put to gather a paper on ___ or do a project on___ and I think that ___ and ___ will do it" it was unreasonable to have the requirements of the class change that frequently and have our work load of the course be something that we could not plan for or account for.
The class sessions need to be better structured. The amount time required for this class with the internship is considerable.
see above.

Two things could improve this course:1) Commit early to the number of students heading to the COP to alleviate the constant uncertainty and strain and allow student to focus on preparing more fully for the conference, delegations and issues on which they will be working.2) Structure the course as other clinics/practicums with students breaking into teams early in the semester to prepare materials related to their specific assignment. (i.e. Team 1 on mitigation prepares briefs on each negotiating bloc's mitigation position and presents to class). Professor organizes readings on each issue, but also spends first few weeks of lecture giving an overview of history of each negotiating track and the UN processes before course moves into guest lecture and student presentation phase.
weekly class
More clarification on classes, better structure, more presentations or materials that students can refer to.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The TA, rather than pushing the professor for clarity and answers, fell into the professor's rhythm and style. Asking the TA for clarity was no more useful than asking Prof. Lee.
Prof lee was not very available - naazia was extremely available
The TA was extremely helpful and always able to answer questions.
Fine.
Professor was quick to reply on any urgent or important matters.TA was extremely available and responsive.
TA was very helpful. Instructor didn't have office hours and was not particularly helpful or clear during class.
He was available upon request. The class should have better organized the students participation in country delegations. Assignments should have been done in September,and they were done in October.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: The course is extremely helpful because it allows me to experience what its like to work at the UN. It helps me as I think about the next step after graduation and potential career paths.

In order to complement my training here at FES I was looking for a course with overarching international environmental themes and a good grounding in climate change policy and practice. This course achieved both goals and has helped prepare me for a wealth of jobs in interdisciplinary fields.
This course focused on climate change negotiations, which is a central part of my interest in the MEM program.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To intern at the UN and go to the COP.
Wanted to see what the UN system was all about
I wanted the exposure to international environmental law and negotiation process.
To ge the UN internship and to go to Durban South Africa
To learn about international negotiations for the environment.
See above
Because of the Durban trip
Because of possibility to attend a COP.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes for the UN internship and COP, no for the classroom experience.

Not really - i was disappointed in almost every facet of the class except: 1) getting to know classmates better through group work, 2) getting an inside peek at the UN, and 3) getting to attend Durban although that was kind of a mess too because we were all working for the same mission thus there was redundancy in work - and it wasn't clear if/how the maldives used our contributions.
Yes.
Mixed. See answers above.
I did learn a lot, but I wanted more guidance and direction.

No. Very disappointing (see above for additional explanation). The "semester long" internship ended up being just a handful of days spent in NY (perhaps 5), and much of the class felt like we were waiting for decisions on internships and/or Durban funding. Extremely poor and ineffective planning.
Absolutely.
Weekly class was bad. Durban trip was great. Weekly internship was a good opportunity but required a lot of extra time.
The COP participation did certainly exceeded my expectations. Classes were not very well structured and did not exceed my expectations.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes for the UN internship and COP, no for the classroom experience.
No

I wish I had a more structured understanding of how UN conferences work, and how countries break into groups like AOSIS. I would also like to know more about how countries prepare for these conferences and how they decide upon their positions.
See above answers. It is hard to say test or no.
No.
Yes.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: advantages: got to know classmates and practiced presentation skills
I learnt from other people´s perspectives on the topic we were studying.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I think many of us want the opportunity to experience the UN, and go to the COP. However, having to put up with a very poor and frustrating classroom experience makes it difficult to recommend the class.
Have low expectations for everything, especially the weekly lectures where most people are not paying attention and are instead working on their laptops for other classes.
Be prepared for long but rewarding days whentraveling into the US.
You should be self-motivated about getting what you want to out of this class.
Talk with past students and know what you are getting into before you take the class.
Push to get your internship assignment early. Bug the professor and the TA.

Make sure it is abundantly clear what the funding commitments are regarding the conference trip BEFORE the beginning of the class. In our case, it was very ambiguous and full of mixed messages, much to our chagrin later on.

1) Make the most of your internship at the UN- the doors are open for you to explore as it is most useful for both you and your mission.2) The COPis an overwhelming and frustrating experience for all the national delegates. Consider pairing with one of them to help coordinate and defray work and to share experiences/make the most of this unique chance to sit inside the process. Enjoy it.
Large time requirement. Instructor and weekly class are not particularly rigorous, i.e. I don't feel I learned very much from the weekly class or the instructor.
To request the professor for more structure of classes (power point presentations, etc). To choose the delegations well in advance.
